prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Breach of Contract—Breach of Express Provisions of a Contract—Non-competition clauses

para.paratext: The principles governing restraint of trade are well established. Lord Macnaghten in Nordenfelt v. Maxim Nordenfelt Guns and Ammunition Co.[1] held that all restraints of trade were contrary to public policy and therefore prima facie void unless they could be justified as being in the public interest and reasonable with reference to the interests of the parties involved. This idea was affirmed by McIntyre J. in Doerner v. Bliss & Laughlin Industries Inc.[2] However, subsequent to the Nordenfelt decision, the law of restraint of trade became more flexible. Lord Macmillan in Vancouver Malt & Sake Brewing Co. v. Vancouver Breweries Ltd.[3] held that: “It is no doubt true that the scope of a doctrine which is founded on public policy necessarily alters as economic conditions alter. Public policy is not a constant.”
However while contracts of employment in restraint of trade are viewed by the law as prima facie offensive, the opposite applies to contracts for the sale of goodwill of a business.[4]
In Tank Lining Corp. v. Dunlop Industrial Ltd.,[5] the court held that in order to determine whether to uphold a non-competition clause, the following factors must be reviewed:
Is the clause in restraint of trade?
Is the restraint contrary to public policy and thus prima facie void?
Is the restraint reasonable within the interests of the parties involved?
Is the restraint in the public interest?

Since the answer to the first two questions is nearly always affirmative,[6] the significant issue in the context of cases dealing with confidential business information is whether the last two conditions can be met. If so, the validity of the clause will be upheld. The reasonableness of a covenant will be determined by an examination of the circumstances surrounding each contract.

Is the restraint reasonable with respect to the parties involved? A restrictive covenant must clearly specify details such as time, geographic area and type of business, or it will be struck down by the courts for lack of precision.[7]

In seeking to enforce a restrictive covenant, the plaintiff must establish that the clause is reasonable given the interests of the parties and that it goes no further than is reasonably necessary to protect the plaintiff's interests. Covenants which are wider than required will not be enforced by the courts.

With regard to geographic area, in some cases, restrictive convenants have covered the whole of Canada,[8] or even all the nations of the world.[9] However, a party cannot enforce a non-competition clause covering a geographic area larger than the confines of the business[10] unless such coverage is appropriate given the facts of the particular case.

In the British case of Herbert Morris Ltd. v. Saxelby,[11] a covenant restraining an employee, upon his termination, from engaging, anywhere in the United Kingdom and for seven years, in a special branch of the engineering business, was held to be far wider than necessary to protect the plaintiff's interest, and the clause was struck down by the court.

In Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann,[12] the defendants were employed by a placement agency, Quantum, and they agreed to a restrictive covenant stipulating that they could not engage in any business competitive with the plaintiff's in a defined area for 18 months after termination of their employment. The clause was declared invalid as it “required more protection for the plaintiff than was reasonably necessary”.

The most important consideration with regard to employment contracts is whether or not the restrictive covenant would render the offending party incapable of earning a livelihood in his or her area of expertise. In Bee Chemical Co. v. Plastic Paint and Finish Specialities Ltd.,[13] it was this key factor that led to the acceptance of a specific clause. The covenant, which restrained the three individual defendants from competing with the plaintiff (a specialty paint firm) for a period of three years, was deemed to be reasonable since the evidence indicated that there were numerous paint firms in the United States and Canada which did not compete with the plaintiff and where the defendants could have found employment.

When two competently advised parties or businesses with equal bargaining power enter into a business agreement, only in exceptional cases will the courts overrule the parties' own judgment of what is reasonable.[14] In Tank Lining Corp. v. Dunlop Industrial Ltd.,[15] where both parties were well established companies, Blair J.A. held that there were no circumstances which would justify his “interfering with the judgments of the parties … as to what is reasonable in their respective interests”. The covenant was declared reasonable.

Is the restraint in the public interest? In the past, the courts held that if a contract was shown to be reasonable between the parties involved, it would also be deemed to be in the public interest.[16] However, this argument has since been rejected, and the courts view the two branches of the test for reasonableness as separate.[17] Thus the courts recognize that a private right can create a public wrong. However, the onus is on the party opposing enforcement to establish that the contract is not in the public interest.

Any agreement that contravenes the Competition Act[18] will be held to be unreasonable and will be struck down as contrary to the public interest.[19] However, except in the case of a breach of the Competition Act, the courts have recognized that they are ill-equipped to handle economic and policy arguments, and will restrict their assessment of reasonableness to the particular facts of the case.[20]
